sub_topic: Calculation of the current density in an electrochemical cell
message_1: What is the current density in an electrochemical cell made up of a copper electrode dipped in a copper sulfate solution and a zinc electrode dipped in a zinc sulfate solution, given that the current flowing through the cell is 0.5 A and the surface area of the copper electrode is 10 cm²? The molar mass of copper is 63.55 g/mol and that of zinc is 65.38 g/mol. The concentrations of copper sulfate and zinc sulfate solutions are 0.1 M and 0.05 M respectively.
message_2:
The current density (J) in an electrochemical cell is defined as the current (I) flowing through the cell divided by the surface area (A) of the electrode. In this case, the current (I) is 0.5 A and the surface area (A) of the copper electrode is 10 cm².

To calculate the current density, use the formula:

J = I / A

Convert the surface area from cm² to m²:

10 cm² * (0.01 m / 1 cm)² = 0.001 m²

Now, calculate the current density:

J = 0.5 A / 0.001 m² = 500 A/m²

The current density in the electrochemical cell is 500 A/m².
